title: Expected Return
equation_latex: E[R] = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * E[R_{i}]
notes: This equation calculates the expected return of a portfolio. E[R] represents the portfolio expected return

title: Portfolio Variance
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma^{2}_{p} = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} s \times um_{j=1}^{n} w_{i} * w_{j} * s \times ig \times ma_{i} * s \times ig \times ma_{j} * r \times ho_{i \times j}
notes: This equation calculates the variance of a portfolio. sigma^2_p represents the portfolio variance

title: Portfolio Standard Deviation
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{p} = s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (s \times ig \times ma^{2}_{p})
notes: This equation calculates the standard deviation (volatility) of a portfolio. sigma_p represents the portfolio volatility

title: Covariance
equation_latex: C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Modern Portfolio Theory

title: Correlation Coefficient
equation_latex: r \times ho_{i \times j} = C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Modern Portfolio Theory

title: Sharpe Ratio
equation_latex: S \times ha \times rp \times e = (E[R_{p}] - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma_{p}
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio

title: Treynor Ratio
equation_latex: T \times re \times yn \times or = (E[R_{p}] - R_{f}) / b \times et \times a_{p}
notes: This equation calculates the Treynor ratio

title: Jensen's Alpha
equation_latex: a \times lp \times ha = R_{p} - (R_{f} + b \times et \times a_{p} * (R_{m} - R_{f}))
notes: This equation calculates Jensen's alpha

title: Information Ratio
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R0__ = (R_{p} - R_{b}) / s \times ig \times ma_{t \times ra \times ck \times in \times g}
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio

title: Tracking Error
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{t \times ra \times ck \times in \times g} = s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{p} - R_{b}))
notes: This equation calculates the tracking error of a portfolio relative to a benchmark. sigma_tracking represents the standard deviation of the difference between portfolio return R_p and benchmark return R_b. Tracking error measures how closely the portfolio follows its benchmark.

title: Capital Allocation Line
equation_latex: R_{p} = R_{f} + (E[R_{m}] - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma_{m} * s \times ig \times ma_{p}
notes: This equation defines the Capital Allocation Line (CAL). R_p represents the return of a portfolio on the CAL

title: Capital Market Line
equation_latex: R_{p} = R_{f} + (E[R_{m}] - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma_{m} * s \times ig \times ma_{p}
notes: This equation defines the Capital Market Line (CML)

title: Security Market Line
equation_latex: E[R_{i}] = R_{f} + b \times et \times a_{i} * (E[R_{m}] - R_{f})
notes: This equation defines the Security Market Line (SML) from CAPM. E[R_i] represents the expected return of asset i

title: Beta
equation_latex: b \times et \times a_{i} = C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Modern Portfolio Theory

title: Portfolio Beta
equation_latex: b \times et \times a_{p} = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * b \times et \times a_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the beta of a portfolio. beta_p represents the portfolio beta

title: Efficient Frontier Optimization
equation_latex: m \times in \times si \times gm \times a^{2}_{p} s \times ub \times je \times ct \times to \times E[R_{p}] = t \times ar \times ge \times t_{r \times et \times ur \times n} a \times nd \times su \times m w_{i} = 1
notes: This equation defines the mean-variance optimization problem for finding the efficient frontier. The objective is to minimize portfolio variance subject to achieving a target return and the weights summing to 1. The efficient frontier contains all optimal portfolios.

title: Minimum Variance Portfolio
equation_latex: w_{m \times vp} = (S \times ig \times ma^{-1} * 1) / (1' * S \times ig \times ma^{-1} * 1)
notes: This equation calculates the weights of the global minimum variance portfolio. w_mvp represents the portfolio weights

title: Tangency Portfolio
equation_latex: w_{t \times an} = (S \times ig \times ma^{-1} * (E[R] - R_{f} * 1)) / (1' * S \times ig \times ma^{-1} * (E[R] - R_{f} * 1))
notes: This equation calculates the weights of the tangency portfolio (maximum Sharpe ratio portfolio). w_tan represents the portfolio weights

title: Value at Risk (Parametric)
equation_latex: V \times aR_{a \times lp \times ha} = m \times u_{p} - z_{a \times lp \times ha} * s \times ig \times ma_{p}
notes: This equation calculates the parametric (normal) VaR. VaR_alpha represents the maximum loss at confidence level alpha

title: Value at Risk (Historical)
equation_latex: V \times aR_{a \times lp \times ha} = -p \times er \times ce \times nt \times il \times e \t \times im \times es (r \times et \times ur \times ns
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Metrics

title: Expected Shortfall (CVaR)
equation_latex: E \times S_{a \times lp \times ha} = E[L \times os \times s | L \times os \times s >= V \times aR_{a \times lp \times ha}]
notes: This equation calculates Expected Shortfall (also called Conditional VaR or CVaR). ES_alpha represents the expected loss given that the loss exceeds VaR_alpha. ES is a coherent risk measure that considers tail risk beyond VaR.

title: Expected Shortfall (Normal)
equation_latex: E \times S_{a \times lp \times ha} = m \times u_{p} - (p \times hi \t \times im \times es (z_{a \times lp \times ha}) / (1 - a \times lp \times ha)) * s \times ig \times ma_{p}
notes: This equation calculates ES under the normal distribution. ES_alpha represents the expected shortfall

title: Incremental VaR
equation_latex: I \times Va \times R_{i} = V \times aR_{p \times or \times tf \times ol \times io} - V \times aR_{w \times it \times ho \times ut}_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the incremental VaR of an asset. IVaR_i represents the change in portfolio VaR when asset i is removed. Incremental VaR helps identify which assets contribute most to portfolio risk. Positive IVaR means the asset increases risk.

title: Marginal VaR
equation_latex: M \times Va \times R_{i} = d \times el \times ta_{__A \times BB \times R0__} / d \times el \times ta_{w}_{i} = C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Metrics

title: Component VaR
equation_latex: C \times Va \times R_{i} = w_{i} * M \times Va \times R_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the component VaR of an asset. CVaR_i represents the contribution of asset i to total portfolio VaR

title: Risk Contribution
equation_latex: R \times is \times k_{i} = w_{i} * C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Metrics

title: Maximum Drawdown
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R0__ = m \times ax \t \times im \times es ((P \times ea \times k_{t} - T \times ro \times ug \times h_{t}) / P \times ea \times k_{t})
notes: This equation calculates the maximum drawdown of a portfolio. MDD represents the largest peak-to-trough decline

title: Average Drawdown
equation_latex: A \times DD = a \times ve \times ra \times ge \times of \times al \times l d \times ra \times wd \times ow \times ns
notes: This equation calculates the average drawdown of a portfolio. ADD represents the average of all drawdowns over the period. Average drawdown complements maximum drawdown by providing information about typical loss severity.

title: Sterling Ratio
equation_latex: S \times te \times rl \times in \times g = (E[R_{p}] - R_{f}) / a \times ve \times ra \times ge_{d \times ra \times wd \times ow \times n}
notes: This equation calculates the Sterling ratio

title: Calmar Ratio
equation_latex: C \times al \times ma \times r = (E[R_{p}] - R_{f}) / __A \times BB \times R0__
notes: This equation calculates the Calmar ratio

title: Sortino Ratio
equation_latex: S \times or \times ti \times no = (E[R_{p}] - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma_{d \times ow \times ns \times id \times e}
notes: This equation calculates the Sortino ratio

title: Downside Deviation
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{d \times ow \times ns \times id \times e} = s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (a \times ve \times ra \times ge \times of \times mi \times n \t \times im \times es (R_{i} - R_{f}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Metrics

title: Omega Ratio
equation_latex: O \times me \times ga \t \times im \times es (a \times lp \times ha) = E[m \times ax \t \times im \times es (R_{p} - a \times lp \times ha

title: Single-Factor Model
equation_latex: R_{i} = a \times lp \times ha_{i} + b \times et \times a_{i} * R_{m} + e \times ps \times il \times on_{i}
notes: This equation defines the single-factor (market) model. R_i represents the return of asset i

title: Multi-Factor Model
equation_latex: R_{i} = a \times lp \times ha_{i} + s \times um_{j=1}^{k} b \times et \times a_{i \times j} * F_{j} + e \times ps \times il \times on_{i}
notes: This equation defines a multi-factor model. R_i represents the return of asset i

title: Fama-French Three-Factor Model
equation_latex: R_{i} = a \times lp \times ha_{i} + b \times et \times a_{i} * (R_{m} - R_{f}) + s_{i} * S \times MB + h_{i} * H \times ML + e \times ps \times il \times on_{i}
notes: This equation defines the Fama-French three-factor model. R_i represents the return

title: Carhart Four-Factor Model
equation_latex: R_{i} = a \times lp \times ha_{i} + b \times et \times a_{i} * (R_{m} - R_{f}) + s_{i} * S \times MB + h_{i} * H \times ML + m_{i} * M \times OM + e \times ps \times il \times on_{i}
notes: This equation defines the Carhart four-factor model. R_i represents the return

title: Idiosyncratic Risk
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{e \times ps \times il \times on}_{i}^{2} = V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{i}) - b \times et \times a_{i}^{2} * V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{m})
notes: This equation calculates the idiosyncratic (unsystematic) variance of an asset. sigma_epsilon_i^2 represents the variance of the asset-specific return

title: Systematic Risk
equation_latex: s \times ig \times ma_{s \times ys \times te \times ma \times ti \times c}^{2} = b \times et \times a_{i}^{2} * V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{m})
notes: This equation calculates the systematic variance of an asset. sigma_systematic^2 represents the variance due to market movements

title: R-squared
equation_latex: R^{2} = 1 - V \times ar \t \times im \times es (e \times ps \times il \times on_{i}) / V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{i})
notes: This equation calculates the R-squared of a factor model. R^2 represents the proportion of return variance explained by the factor model. R^2 close to 1 indicates that the factor model explains most of the return variation.

title: Tracking Error Volatility
equation_latex: T \times EV = s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es (V \times ar \t \times im \times es (R_{p} - R_{b}))
notes: This equation calculates the tracking error volatility. TEV represents the standard deviation of the active return (difference between portfolio return R_p and benchmark return R_b). TEV measures the active risk taken by the portfolio manager.

title: Active Share
equation_latex: A \times ct \times iv \times e S \times ha \times re = 0.5 * s \times um |w_{p}
notes: i|

title: Rolling Beta
equation_latex: b \times et \times a_{r \times ol \times li \times ng} = C \times ov_{r \times ol \times li \times ng}(R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Factor Models

title: Risk Parity
equation_latex: w_{i} = 1 / s \times ig \times ma_{i} / s \times um_{j=1}^{n} (1 / s \times ig \times ma_{j})
notes: This equation calculates the weights for a risk parity portfolio. w_i represents the weight of asset i

title: Equal Risk Contribution
equation_latex: E \times RC_{i} = w_{i} * C \times ov \t \times im \times es (R_{i}
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Management

title: Risk Budgeting
equation_latex: T \times ar \times ge \times t R \times is \times k C \times on \times tr \times ib \times ut \times io \times n_{i} = b_{i} * s \times ig \times ma_{p}^{2}
notes: This equation defines the risk budgeting condition. Target Risk Contribution_i represents the desired risk contribution of asset i

title: Kelly Criterion
equation_latex: f = (m \times u - R_{f}) / s \times ig \times ma^{2}
notes: This equation calculates the optimal fraction of capital to invest (Kelly criterion). f represents the optimal fraction
